awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity to Expand Recruitment and High-Quality Preparation of Secondary STEM Teachers in High-Need Districts in Rural Virginia
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to address the national need to prepare high-quality secondary STEM teachers to serve in high-need school districts.  It intends to address shortages of high-quality secondary STEM teachers in rural Virginia by building streamlined pathways for STEM majors to complete both a STEM degree and teacher licensure in four years.  This will occur through collaboration of Hollins University STEM and education faculty for the purpose of being able to recruit biology, chemistry, and mathematics majors to complete their STEM baccalaureate degree with teacher licensure as undergraduates.  Through this Capacity Building project, Hollins University, a women’s university in Roanoke, Virginia, will develop recruitment strategies to attract STEM students to secondary STEM teaching careers in local high-need schools.  In addition, the project will enable transfer STEM students to complete both a STEM degree and teaching licensure in two years. To meet the needs of students from diverse backgrounds or from low-income communities in the region, the project will integrate culturally and linguistically inclusive teaching methods into the revised teacher education curriculum. These efforts will prepare future STEM teachers to work effectively with secondary student populations in rural Virginia.

This Capacity Building project at Hollins University includes partnerships with Virginia Western Community College (VWCC) and two high-need schools, William Fleming High School and Lucy Addison Middle School.  Hollins STEM and education faculty will reevaluate the STEM and education curricula to create streamlined pathways for STEM undergraduate students to complete their STEM degrees and teacher licensure within four years.  Culturally and linguistically inclusive teaching methods will be integrated into the revised curricula coursework to prepare future teachers to effectively support learners from diverse backgrounds.  In addition, faculty from both Hollins and Virginia Western Community College will collaborate to develop articulation agreements to support STEM transfer students in completing a STEM degree with teacher licensure within two years. Data will be collected from students, faculty, and advisors about barriers to STEM teaching careers. These data will be used to build a recruitment strategy to attract STEM undergraduate students in biology, chemistry, and mathematics to pursue STEM teaching licensure and careers in the region. Partnerships with representatives from the community college and high-need schools, along with integration of culturally and linguistically inclusive pedagogy, have the potential to produce highly qualified STEM teachers prepared to serve increasingly diverse student populations in Virginia’s rural high-need schools. Evaluation of the project will be conducted by Brockport Research Institute through interviews with project stakeholders and on-going review of documents produced by collaborative stakeholder teams. Outcomes of the effort will be disseminated through national and regional teacher education conferences, as well as communications with local and regional educational agencies. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the retention and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to attract more students (transfer, first-year, and current students) interested in becoming science or mathematics teachers and working in high-need local education agencies (LEAs) and communities. The project team planned to carefully examine and streamline the STEM (math, biology, chemistry) and education pathways to ensure that students could complete the requirements for both a STEM major and teacher licensure in four years. Another goal was to ensure that our curriculum incorporated high-impact practices related to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) to help ensure the success of students who would ultimately enter the program. Our proposal incorporated partnerships with LEAs and local community college partners to identify best practices to meet the needs of both first-year college students and students who transfer from community college.

Several significant outcomes resulted from our work. First, we conducted monthly training sessions on culturally responsive pedagogy. While the goal was to ensure that STEM and education faculty would learn about and implement high-impact practices in this area, the training sessions were advertised to all faculty. Approximately 25 faculty members from across campus and the local community college attended one or more of these training sessions, and many faculty members reported incorporating new practices into their teaching with positive results. This resulted in STEM and education faculty and colleagues trained to educate a diverse student population.

Through our work reviewing curricula at other institutions as well as our own, the project team identified many institutions that have implemented STEM education majors (Biology Education, Math Education, Chemistry Education) to steamline the pathway leading to a major in a STEM field and secondary licensure. Many of our students who began the education program with the intent to become a teacher licensed in secondary education ultimately decided not to pursue licensure because of the significant number of additional courses that were required. These students preferred to pursue additional elective courses or a minor to go along with their major. Our goal was to mitigate this barrier to completion, but we also placed a high priority on maintaining the requirement to major in the subject-specific field; thus, we crafted a proposal for a minor in secondary education that provides recognition for students’ significant accomplishments on their diploma and their transcript. This proposal passed and was implemented in the 2023-2024 academic year.

Our curriculum review also resulted in a careful examination of the overlap between the requirements for a STEM major and the requirements for a minor in secondary education. Through meaningful, ongoing conversations between STEM and education faculty, we identified barriers students face in meeting the requirements for both programs and developed new major maps that allow students’ internships and senior theses/projects to meet the requirements for both their major and their minor in secondary education.

In addition to the successful outcomes of the project, we also faced barriers that impeded our ability to accomplish all our goals.  First, the university was redesigning the general education curriculum and preparing for program launch in 2023-24. The partially developed curriculum left us with many unanswered questions about how courses in the major and minor would contribute to general education requirements, and we were ultimately unable to finalize a curriculum before the end of the project timeline. The uncertainty around the new general education curriculum also impeded our ability to finalize documentation for Transfer Virginia, a statewide effort to formalize transfer agreements between universities and community colleges in Virginia, before the end of the project timeline. Transfer guides have now been submitted for final review by Transfer Virginia administrators before being published in the online system.

While our goal was to collaborate with LEAs to identify high-impact practices that would be helpful for incoming students and advertise our program to potential students, identifying teachers or other appropriate staff members to participate in this project proved to be more of a challenge than anticipated. We were ultimately unable to locate teachers who had the capacity to collaborate on this project. While this impeded our ability to accomplish one of the goals of our project, it was also a helpful outcome of the project because it highlighted the need for a strong relationship with external partners before project implementation. The education program has therefore secured building-level relationships with principals at high-need schools, and we will begin working solely with those select schools during the 2024-25 academic year. All education program students will be placed in one of those schools for their student teaching field placements moving forward, and education faculty and building administrators will meet regularly to review and enhance programming to best meet the needs of all stakeholders. These partnerships will help us identify high-impact practices that will benefit students as well as recruit new students to our programs.

 


Last Modified: 04/17/2024
Modified by: Teri R Wagner
